frameDefinitions: In this frame a Hindrance makes it more difficult for a Protagonist to complete their intended Action or a Hindrance directly affects an Action where the Action can be a natural act or the actions of many individuals in a collective endeavor.
An Item is in a state of wetness with the possibility of the wetting Liquid being mentioned, along with the Degree of wetness. '
An Entity has the ability to contain a Theme.
In this frame a Container holds within its physical boundaries the Contents.

This frame involves a static (primarily spatial) relationship between a Location and a Theme, in which the Theme is located in many or all subregions of the Location, and is thus construable as covering it.
An Agent causes a Speaker to become silent, sometimes about a particular Topic.
frameExamples: Malcolm was <t>hindered</t> by his drinking problem .
The mop is <t>drenched</t> with water from last night's rain.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Protagonist</fen> is the entity that tends towards or plans some <fen>Action</fen> which the <fen>Hindrance</fen> causes to be more difficult.
The <fen>Hindrance</fen> is the force which makes the <fen>Action</fen> more difficult or less likely to be successfully completed. The <fen>Hindrance</fen> may be a lack of enabling force:

The <fen>Action</fen> is what the <fen>Protagonist</fen> desires to do, which is made more difficult by the <fen>Hindrance</fen>. It can also be a natural act or collective endeavor, not linked to an overt <fen>Protagonist</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the <fen>Hindrance</fen> affects the <fen>Protagonist</fen> or <fen>Action</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location where  he <fen>Hindrance</fen> affects the <fen>Protagonist</fen> or <fen>Action</fen>.
The <fen>Item</fen> takes up the <fen>Liquid</fen> through its pores.
The <fen>Liquid</fen> is a fluid or gas that permeates the <fen>Item</fen>.  It most frequently occurs in a PP Complement headed by with.
The <fen>Entity</fen> whose ability to contain items is assessed.
The <fen>Entity</fen> has the ability to contain the <fen>Theme</fen>, often expressed with a quantity.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Entity</fen> has or had a certain capacity.
The <fen>Container</fen> is the physical object which holds within its boundaries the <fen>Contents</fen>
The <fen>Contents</fen> is the substance or objects contained within the physical bounds of the <fen>Container</fen>.
The time at which the <fen>Container</fen> holds the <fen>Contents</fen>.

The <fen>Theme</fen> in this frame is the object which is described as standing in some spatial relation to a particular <fen>Location</fen>.  <fen>Theme</fen> typically occurs as the External Argument or, with passives, as a PP Complement headed by 'with' or 'by'.
<fen>Location</fen> is the entity or area with respect to which the <fen>Theme</fen>'s spatial arrangement is described.  This frame element generally occurs as an NP Object.
The time at which the <fen>Theme</fen> occupies the <fen>Location</fen>.
The Agent is the person performing the intentional act.
The sentient entity that is not communicating.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the <fen>Speaker</fen>'s voice or other communicative noise emitted by the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
listRoleExamples: The project was hampered <fex>by a lack of funds</fex>.
The mop was drenched <fex> with water</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: Choice as an Outstanding Academic Book
the Cith Hall and Opera House
“Device for Raising and Lowering Floors of Theaters
New England Yankee Ingenuity: The Moveable Opera House Floors of George Gilman Adams
Circle Stock Theatre: Touring American Small Towns, 1900-1960
